**Mortality (M):**-- The deaths in the population from all causes (natural mortality like disease/predation, plus fishing mortality) **Types of Mortality:** 1. **Natural mortality (M)** - Disease, predation, starvation, old age 1. **Fishing mortality (F)** - Deaths from fishing 1. **Total mortality (Z)** - Sum of natural and fishing mortality Z = M + F ## [Mortality (M)...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Mortality characteristics:** - Often higher at young ages - May increase with old age - Fishing mortality controllable, natural not - Varies by season and location ## [Mortality Illustration]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ```{mermaid} graph TD A["Starting Population
1000 fish"] --> B["Natural Mortality
50 fish die"] A --> C["Fishing Mortality
200 fish caught"] B --> D["Survivors
750 fish"] C --> D D --> E["Total Mortality = 25%"] ``` ## [Population Models]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ### [Mathematical Tools for Prediction]{style="background: #453d42ff; color: #f6773cff"} ## [Model Basics]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **What is a Population Model?** - Mathematical representation of how population changes - Uses vital rates (recruitment, growth, mortality) - Predicts future population size - Basis for harvest decisions ## [Model Basics...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Simple Population Equation:** $$N_{t+1} = N_t + R_t - M_t - C_t$$ Where: - $N_t$ = population at time t - $R_t$ = recruitment - $M_t$ = natural mortality - $C_t$ = catch ## [Exponential Growth Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} - The **Exponential Growth Model** describes population growth when there are no resource limitations. - It assumes that the population grows at a constant rate, leading to exponential increase over time. **Formula:** $$N_t = N_0 e^{rt}$$ Or equivalently: $$N_t = N_0 \lambda^t$$ ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Where:** - $N_t$ = population size at time t - $N_0$ = initial population size - $r$ = intrinsic rate of increase (growth rate) - $\lambda$ = population growth rate - $t$ = time ::: ::: {.column} **What it means:** - If $r > 0$: population grows exponentially - If $r = 0$: population stable - If $r < 0$: population declines or shrink ::: ::: ## [Exponential Growth Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Assumption:** ***1. Unlimited resources*** + Food is always available + Space is not limiting + No environmental constraints + Habitat quality doesn't change ::: ::: {.column} ***Exponential growth curve:*** ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## [Exponential Growth Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Assumption:** ***2. Constant Growth Rate (r)*** + Growth rate doesn't change over time + Same regardless of population size + Environmental conditions stable + No density-dependent effects ::: ::: {.column} ***Exponential growth curve:*** ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## [Exponential Growth Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Assumption:** ***3. No Density Dependence*** + Population size doesn't affect vital rates + Birth rate stays constant regardless of how many fish there are + Death rate stays constant + Competition doesn't increase with density ::: ::: {.column} ***Exponential growth curve:*** ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## [Exponential Growth Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Assumption:** ***4. Closed Population*** + No immigration (fish moving in) + No emigration (fish moving out) + All changes come from births and deaths only ::: ::: {.column} ***Exponential growth curve:*** ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## [Exponential Growth Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Assumption:** ***5. Continuous Population*** + Applies to every individual equally + No age/size structure effects + Simplified view of population ::: ::: {.column} ***Exponential growth curve:*** ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## [Exponential Growth Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Assumption:** ***6. No Fishing or External Removal*** + All removals are natural deaths only + Assumes no harvesting ::: ::: {.column} ***Exponential growth curve:*** ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: # [Why these assumptions are unrealistic?]{style="color: #bebe56ff"} ## [Problem with Exponential Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} - Ignores resource limits + Fish DO have limits (food, space, oxygen) - Predicts infinite growth + Growth rates **DO** change with density + Competition **DOES** increase when crowded + Real populations have age/size structure - Unrealistic + Fisheries involve harvesting ## [Logistic Growth Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} - Logistic growth model is more realistic for fish populations than the exponential growth model. - It incorporates the concept of carrying capacity (K), which represents the maximum population size that the environment can sustain indefinitely and density-dependent effects. ::: ::: {.column} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## [Logistic Growth Model...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Assumption:** Growth limited by carrying capacity (K) **Formula:** $$\frac{dN}{dt} = rN\left(1 - \frac{N}{K}\right)$$ Or in discrete form: $$N_{t+1} = N_t + rN_t\left(1 - \frac{N_t}{K}\right)$$ Where: - $r$ = intrinsic rate of increase - $K$ = carrying capacity (maximum population) - $(1 - N_t/K)$ = density-dependent factor ## [Logistic Growth Model...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **What it means:** - Growth slows as population approaches K - Equilibrium at K - More realistic for real populations ::: ::: {.column} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## Logistic Growth Dynamics ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **At different population levels:** - **When N < K:** Population grows rapidly - **When N = K/2:** Population growth is fastest - **When N approaches K:** Population growth slows dramatically - **When N = K:** Population is stable (if no fishing) **For Fisheries:** - MSY often achieved near K/2 - Overfishing reduces population below optimal levels ::: ::: {.column} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## [Exponential Growth curve Vs Logistic Growth]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ```{=html} ``` ## [Stock-Recruitment Relationships]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ### [Connecting Spawners to Offspring]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ## [What is Stock-Recruitment?]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Definition:** The relationship between spawning stock size and recruitment (number of young fish produced) **Key Idea:** - More spawners = more eggs - But relationship may not be linear - Environmental variation matters - Density-dependent effects ## [Beverton-Holt Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} - The Beverton-Holt model is a commonly used stock-recruitment relationship in fisheries science. **Formula:** $$R_t = \frac{aS_t}{1 + bS_t}$$ Where: - $R_t$ = recruitment at time t - $S_t$ = spawning stock size - $a$ = productivity parameter (maximum recruitment potential) - $b$ = density-dependent parameter (strength of density dependence) ## [Beverton-Holt Model...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Characteristics:** - Recruitment increases with spawners - Recruitment plateaus at high spawning stock (asymptotic) - Maximum recruitment = $a/b$ - Good for species with strong density-dependent effects ::: ::: {.column} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ## [How Beverton-Holt Works]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **At low spawning stock (S_t small):** - Recruitment increases nearly linearly with spawners - Few density-dependent effects - Each new spawner adds substantially to recruitment ::: ::: {.column} **At high spawning stock (S_t large):** - Recruitment plateaus (approaches maximum) - Density-dependent effects dominate - Competition for food/space reduces per-capita recruitment - Additional spawners add little to total recruitment ::: ::: ## [Mathematical insight of Beverton-Holt model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Formula:** $$R_t = \frac{aS_t}{1 + bS_t}$$ ::: ::: {.column} - When $S_t = 0$: $R_t = 0$ (no spawners = no recruitment) - When $S_t$ → ∞: $R_t$ → $a/b$ (maximum recruitment) ::: ::: ## [Ricker Model]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Formula:** $$R_t = aS_t e^{-bS_t}$$ Where: - $a$ = productivity parameter - $b$ = density-dependent parameter ## [Ricker Model...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Characteristics:** - Recruitment increases then decreases - Peak recruitment at intermediate spawning stock - Decline at very high spawner numbers - Good for species (salmon) with cannibalism or crowding effects ## [Beverton-Holt vs. Ricker]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ```{=html} ``` **Key Difference:** - **Beverton-Holt:** More spawners = more recruitment (asymptotic) - **Ricker:** Too many spawners can reduce recruitment (hump-shaped) ## Variability in Recruitment ```{mermaid} graph TD A["Spawning Stock Size"] --> B["Environmental
Variation"] A --> C["Larval Food
Availability"] A --> D["Temperature
& Currents"] A --> E["Predation
Pressure"] B --> F["Recruitment
Uncertainty"] C --> F D --> F E --> F ``` **Practical Implication:** - Can't predict recruitment precisely - Must account for uncertainty - Risk of recruitment failure ## [Density-Dependent Effects]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ### [How Population Density Matters]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ## [What is Density Dependence?]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Density Dependence:**-- When vital rates (growth, survival, reproduction) depend on population density **How it works:** - High density → increased competition - Competition for food, space, mates - Reduced growth and survival - Lower recruitment ## [Density Dependence...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Equation:** $$\text{Vital Rate} = f(\text{Population Size})$$ **Meaning**: Vital Rate is a function of Population Size - The vital rate changes depends on how many fish are in the population - It is a mathematical function where population size is the input ## [Density Dependence...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Example 1: Growth Rate** $$Growth~Rate = f(Population~Size)$$ - **Small population**: Fish have plenty of food → Fast growth - **Large population**: Competition for food → Slow growth - Same species, different growth rate based on population density ## [Density Dependence...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Example 2: Survival Rate** $$Survival~Rate = f(Population~Size)$$ - **Small population**: Low mortality (abundant resources) → High survival - **Large population**: High mortality (starvation, disease) → Low survival ## [Density Dependence...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Example 3: Reproduction Rate** $$Reproduction~Rate = f(Population~Size)$$ - **Small population**: Fish produce many eggs → High recruitment * **Large population**: Fish produce fewer eggs → Low recruitment ## [Density Dependence...]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **In contrast, WITHOUT density dependence:** $$Vital~Rate = constant$$ - Vital Rate does not change with population size ## [Summary of Density Dependence]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} **Growth:** - Dense populations grow slower - Limited food per fish - Smaller fish at same age **Survival:** - Dense populations have higher mortality - Starvation increases - Disease spreads easier **Reproduction:** - Dense populations produce fewer recruits - Smaller eggs - Lower reproductive success ## [Density Dependence in Logistic Growth]{style="background: #4a1035ff; color: #bebe56ff"} ```{=html} ``` **Key insight:** - Growth rate = 0 at K (equilibrium) - Maximum growth rate at K/2 - This is where MSY occurs in logistic model ## Thank you! **Questions?**
